Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was negative for metastases. We evaluated the responsiveness of tumor to chemotherapy, based on Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST), version 1.1.
In August 2012, chemotherapy with cisplatin and pemetrexed was initiated, resulting in stable disease after four courses, followed by seven cycles of pemetrexed continuation maintenance therapy. Although she achieved stable disease for approximately 9 months, cancer regrowth occurred at the right mediastinal lymph nodes (Figure A).

prompt:

Doctor: Have you noticed any shortness of breath or difficulty breathing when lying down?

Doctor: Okay, I see that you have a history of severe IBD and are on mesalamine and infliximab. Have you noticed any improvement in your gastrointestinal symptoms lately?
Patient: No, I actually have been having three to four dark, bloody bowel movements a day and abdominal pain for two weeks.
Doctor: I see. We may need to adjust your medication. Let's take a look at your vitals. (after examining) Your mucous membranes are pale and dry, and your EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads I and aVL. I'm going to order some lab work and imaging to better understand what's going on.

chosen_response:
A 37-year-old male with a history of severe IBD, on mesalamine and infliximab, and non-ischemic stress-induced cardiomyopathy with a recovered ejection fraction of 50%-55% two years prior presented to the emergency department with complaints of moderate to severe, worsening, constant substernal pleuritic chest pain for three days. He endorsed a dry cough and low-grade fevers. He denied orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, weight gain, leg swelling, palpitations, or pre-syncope. He also reported three to four dark, bloody bowel movements a day accompanied by abdominal pain and tenesmus for two weeks. These symptoms were attributed to Crohn's flare-up, prompting the initiation of prednisone 40 mg daily for one week followed by a taper with an increase in the dose of mesalamine from 1200 mg to 1600 mg three times daily. He experienced minimal improvement in his gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient denied the use of tobacco, alcohol, or other illicit drugs. Of note, he reported feeling a similar chest pain during his flare-up two years prior.
At the time of arrival, the patient was febrile to 100.60 F, with other vitals unremarkable. Mucous membranes were pale and dry. Lungs were clear to auscultation. The patient had a hyperdynamic precordium, loud S1 and S2, and grade II pan-systolic murmur heard at the apex with radiation to the axilla. He had tenderness to touch in the right lower quadrant with associated guarding and rigidity, but no rebound tenderness. He had regular peripheral pulses with well-perfused extremities. Doctor: I see. You were admitted to the hospital because of your deteriorating angina symptoms, right?

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: Can you tell me more about your medical history?

Patient: I have a history of coronary artery disease and I've had a PCI of the LAD and recanalization of LCx chronic total occlusion with proximal stent implantation using the T-stent technique.

Patient: Yes, I remember.

Doctor: Unfortunately, the Xience Pro 2.25 × 23 mm stent got stuck at the proximal edge of the LCx stent.

Patient: Oh no.

Doctor: We tried using a buddy wire to facilitate the stent deployment, but it proved unsuccessful.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: So, we decided to use the small buddy balloon catheter technique with a Mini Trek 1.5 × 15 mm balloon positioned at the site of the stuck stent.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: This technique allowed for a smooth delivery of the stent to the lesion.

Patient: That's good to hear.

Doctor: After retrieving the buddy wire with the buddy balloon catheter, we successfully deployed the stent and the procedure was completed.

Patient: Thank you, doctor.

Doctor: You're welcome. I would like to see you again in a week for a follow-up appointment to check on your progress.

Patient: Sure, I'll be there.

chosen_response:
A 73-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with deteriorating angina symptoms, CCS (Canadian Cardiovascular Society) functional class III, for coronary angiography. She had a history of coronary artery disease with PCI of the LAD as well as recanalization of LCx chronic total occlusion with proximal stent implantation using the T-stent technique.
Coronary angiography revealed subtotal occlusion of the LCx distally to the previously implanted stent. The decision to revascularize the LCx with drug-eluting stent implantation by a radial approach and using a 6F EBU 3.5 guiding catheter was made. After crossing the lesion with a Sion Blue guidewire, pre-dilation with a semi-compliant TREK balloon (Abbott Vascular) 2.5 × 15 mm was performed. Surprisingly, the Xience Pro 2.25 × 23 mm stent was stuck at the proximal edge of the LCx stent (). In the next step, a buddy wire was used to facilitate the stent deployment in the artery, but this technique also proved unsuccessful. Finally, the operator decided to use the small buddy balloon catheter technique with a Mini Trek 1.5 × 15 mm balloon positioned at the site of the stuck stent (). This technique allowed for a smooth delivery of the stent to the lesion (). After retrieving the buddy wire with the buddy balloon catheter, successful stent deployment was performed and the procedure was completed.

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Did you experience any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or fever?

Patient: No, I didn't have any of those.

Doctor: Okay. We did some hematologic and chemical blood tests on you when you were admitted, and the results were normal except for an elevated WBC count, CRP level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?

Doctor: It means that there may be some inflammation in your body. We did an Upper endoscopy and found a central ulcer on a submucosal tumor-like lesion with surrounding mucosal edema on the greater curvature of the gastric midbody.

Patient: What's that?

Doctor: It's a growth in your stomach. We took a biopsy and found ulceration and inflammatory cell infiltration. An abdominal CT showed a localized and inhomogeneous enhanced submucosal mass of about 3 cm in size. And endoscopic ultrasonography showed a 3 cm by 2.5 cm sized heterogeneous submucosal occupied mass on the greater curvature of the gastric midbody.

Patient: Is it cancer?

Doctor: The biopsy results showed that it's not a malignant condition, but we still considered surgery because it might have been a gastrointestinal stromal tumor and due to the size of the submucosal mass.

Patient: What did you do?

Doctor: We performed a laparoscopic gastric wedge resection. The histopathological examination showed severe inflammatory cell infiltration, edema, and abscess formation with a submucosal eosinophilic granuloma around the larvae, which are findings consistent with gastric anisakiasis.

Patient: What's that?

Doctor: It's a type of infection caused by eating raw fish. Your postoperative course was uneventful, which is good news.

He did not complain of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or fever. The results of all the hematologic and chemical blood tests were normal on admission, with the exception of an elevated WBC count, CRP level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Upper endoscopy showed a central ulcer on a submucosal tumor-like lesion with surrounding mucosal edema on the greater curvature of the gastric midbody (). Examination of biopsy specimens revealed ulceration and inflammatory cell infiltration. Abdominal CT showed a localized and inhomogeneous enhanced submucosal mass of approximately 3 cm in size on the greater curvature of the gastric midbody (). Moreover, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) showed a 3-cm- × 2.5-cm-sized heterogeneous submucosal occupied mass on the greater curvature of the gastric midbody ().
Although the biopsy results proved that this was not a malignant condition, surgery was considered because the tumor may have been a gastrointestinal stromal tumor and due to the size of the submucosal mass (3 cm). A laparoscopic gastric wedge resection was performed and histopathological examination showed severe inflammatory cell infiltration, edema, and abscess formation with a submucosal eosinophilic granuloma around the larvae, which are findings consistent with gastric anisakiasis (). The patient's postoperative course was uneventful.

Computed tomography indicated deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity and significant stenosis of the left common iliac vein and compression by right iliac artery. May-Thurner syndrome with deep vein thrombosis was diagnosed (Fig. a). The delay between the thrombotic event and the procedure was 9 days. A filter was placed in the inferior vena cava. Then urokinase (1 million u/day) was pumped. The venography after 2 days showed that the residual amount of thrombus decreased significantly. Three days later, venography showed that the stenosis in left common iliac vein was exposed clearly. So, stent implantation was decided and two 14 mm*60 mm and 12 mm*60 mm stents were placed in the left iliac vein (Fig. f-g). prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that generates clinical notes from doctor-patient conversations.

Conversation:

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

Patient: Not so great, doctor. I have been having some pain in my eyes when I move them.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? When did it start?

Patient: It started about two weeks ago, with pain in my left eye when I move it. Then I started to have some visual loss in the same eye. And then a week later, I started to have similar symptoms in my right eye.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. And when you were admitted, what was your vision like?

Patient: My vision was counting fingers in the right eye and I couldn't see anything in the left eye.

Doctor: I see. And did you have any other symptoms besides the eye pain and visual loss?

Patient: Yes, I also had some sensory symptoms in my legs and saddle area with urinary retention.

Doctor: Okay, that's good to know. And when you were examined, was there a sensory level to pinprick in your back?

Patient: Yes, there was a sensory level to pinprick at T8.

Doctor: I see. And what was the appearance of your optic disc like?

Patient: The doctor said it was normal.

Doctor: Okay. And did you have any imaging done?

Patient: Yes, I had MR imaging done.

Doctor: And what did the MR imaging show?

Patient: It showed T2 hyperintensity and enhancement of both optic nerves intracranially just anterior to the chiasm. And my brain appeared normal. But the MR imaging of my spinal cord showed a T2 hyperintense lesion within the distal spinal cord extending across 3 to 4 vertebral segments.

Doctor: I see. And did you have a cerebrospinal fluid examination?

Patient: Yes, I did.

Doctor: And what was the result of the examination?

Patient: There was a white cell count of 59/mm3, 78% of which were lymphocytes and the remainder polymorphs. And there were matched oligoclonal bands present in my CSF and serum.

Doctor: Okay. Based on these results, you were treated with high-dose methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone, correct?

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: And how was your recovery?

Patient: My recovery was excellent. I made a great visual recovery. And when I was seen three months later, my visual acuity was 6/6 in my right eye and 6/9 in my left eye. And I had N5 bilaterally with no mistakes made on the Ishihara plates with either eye.

Doctor: That's great to hear. And did you have any other symptoms after the treatment?

Patient: No, I remained entirely well until a year later when I developed pain on moving my left eye.

Doctor: I see. And did you have any imaging done then?

Patient: Yes, I had MR imaging of my orbits done.

Doctor: And what did the MR imaging show?

Patient: It showed enhancement of my left optic nerve/sheath complex. But there was no loss of vision and my optic disc appearance was unchanged.

Doctor: Okay. And what was your treatment then?

Patient: I was treated immediately following the scan with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone.

Doctor: And how was your vision at the time the steroids were given?

Patient: My visual acuities were recorded as 6/5, N5 bilaterally with full colour vision. And there was no subjective deterioration in vision.

Doctor: That's great to hear. We will continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
